message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Deepfakes and Disinformation: Exploring the Impact of Synthetic Political Video on Deception, Uncertainty, and Trust in News
Paper Abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) now enables the mass creation of what have become known as “deepfakes”: synthetic videos that closely resemble real videos. Integrating theories about the power of visual communication and the role played by uncertainty in undermining trust in public discourse, we explain the likely contribution of deepfakes to online disinformation. Administering novel experimental treatments to a large representative sample of the United Kingdom population allowed us to compare people’s evaluations of deepfakes. We find that people are more likely to feel uncertain than to be misled by deepfakes, but this resulting uncertainty, in turn, reduces trust in news on social media. We conclude that deepfakes may contribute toward generalized indeterminacy and cynicism, further intensifying recent challenges to online civic culture in democratic societies.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Artificial intelligence"

Links: [{"title":"Artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Artificial general intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_general_intelligence"},{"title":"Applications of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Applications_of_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Timeline of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence in video games - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_in_video_games"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence visual art - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_art"},{"title":"Artificial Intelligence: A Modern Approach - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_Intelligence:_A_Modern_Approach"},{"title":"List of artificial intelligence films - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_artificial_intelligence_films"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence arms race - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_arms_race"},{"title":"Ethics of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethics_of_artificial_intelligence"}]

Here's a comprehensive overview of Artificial Intelligence based on the search results:

## Definition

Artificial intelligence (AI) is the capability of computational systems to perform tasks typically associated with human intelligence, such as learning, reasoning, problem-solving, perception, and decision-making.

## Core Goals and Techniques

The traditional goals of AI research include learning, reasoning, knowledge representation, planning, natural language processing, perception, and support for robotics.(no content)To reach these goals, AI researchers have adapted and integrated a wide range of techniques, including search and mathematical optimization, formal logic, artificial neural networks, and methods based on statistics, operations research, and economics.

## Historical Context

Artificial intelligence was founded as an academic discipline in 1956, and the field went through multiple cycles of optimism throughout its history, followed by periods of disappointment and loss of funding, known as AI winters.

## Generative AI

Generative artificial intelligence (Generative AI, or GenAI) is a subfield of artificial intelligence that uses generative models to generate text, images, videos, audio, software code or other forms of data.

## Artificial General Intelligence

Some companies, such as OpenAI, Google DeepMind and Meta, aim to create artificial general intelligence (AGI) – AI that can complete virtually any cognitive task at least as well as a human.

## Applications

AI has become widespread across many sectors, including astronomy, architecture, contact centers, media analysis, video surveillance, music composition, and news generation, among many other fields.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Media Trust - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Media_Trust"},{"title":"Media Standards Trust - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Media_Standards_Trust"},{"title":"SPH Media Trust - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SPH_Media_Trust"},{"title":"Category:Jurnal Trust Media - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Jurnal_Trust_Media"},{"title":"Talk:Media Trust - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Media_Trust"},{"title":"MaineToday Media - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MaineToday_Media"},{"title":"Talk:Daily Mail and General Trust - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Daily_Mail_and_General_Trust"},{"title":"Template talk:Daily Mail and General Trust - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template_talk:Daily_Mail_and_General_Trust"},{"title":"Scott Trust Limited - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scott_Trust_Limited"},{"title":"NetLink Trust - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NetLink_Trust"}]

I've completed the web search for "Trust media." Here are the main results:

## Key Findings:

**Media Companies and Organizations:**

1. Media Trust is a privately held Nigerian newspaper publishing company based in Abuja that publishes the English-language Daily Trust, Weekly Trust, Sunday Trust and the Hausa-language Aminiya newspapers, as well as a new pan-African magazine, Kilimanjaro.

2. The Media Standards Trust is a British media think tank formed in 2006.(no content)It carries out research on issues in the media sector and advocates for press freedom as well as industry quality, transparency and accountability.

3. SPH Media Trust (SMT), trading as SPH Media, is a mass media company in Singapore. It was incorporated on July 19, 2021, as a company limited by guarantee, it was a spin off from Singapore Press Holdings as part of a restructuring.

4. The Scott Trust Limited is the British limited company that owns Guardian Media Group and thus The Guardian as well as various other media businesses in the UK.

5. The Maine Trust for Local News runs the Maine newspapers after the National Trust for Local News purchased them.

The search results show various media trusts and organizations operating across different countries, each with different ownership structures and purposes.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Civic culture"

Links: [{"title":"Civic political culture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civic_political_culture"},{"title":"The Civic Culture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Civic_Culture"},{"title":"Civic engagement - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civic_engagement"},{"title":"Civic nationalism - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civic_nationalism"},{"title":"Civic virtue - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civic_virtue"},{"title":"Civil religion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civil_religion"},{"title":"Political culture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_culture"},{"title":"Civic studies - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civic_studies"},{"title":"Civic education in the United States - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civic_education_in_the_United_States"},{"title":"Civil society - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civil_society"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about civic culture:

## Definition and Core Concepts

A civic culture or civic political culture is a political culture characterized by "acceptance of the authority of the state" and "a belief in participation in civic duties".(no content)The term was first used in Gabriel Almond and Sidney Verba's book, The Civic Culture.(no content)The "civic culture" is "based on communication and persuasion, a culture of consensus and diversity, a culture that [permits] change but [moderates] it".

## Characteristics of Civic Culture

Civic political culture is a mixture of other political cultures namely parochial, subject and participant political cultures.(no content)The term civic culture is used to identify the political culture characteristics that explain the stability of a democratic society's political structure.

Key characteristics include:
- Valuing of active participation in local government activities, parties, and in civic associations
- Strong civic cultures are distinguished by robust support for achieving political homeostasis: the optimal mediated balance between multiple contradictory forces such as in the tension between respect for individual rights and concern for the public good, or that between governmental effectiveness and responsiveness to the interests of citizens.

## Impact on Democratic Societies

The proper combination of the various types of political culture will provide a culture that has a positive implication for the growth of democracy.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

A civic culture or civic political culture is a political culture characterized by "acceptance of the authority of the state" and "a belief in participation in civic duties".(no content)The term was first used in Gabriel Almond and Sidney Verba's book, The Civic Culture.(no content)The "civic culture" is "based on communication and persuasion, a culture of consensus and diversity, a culture that [permits] change but [moderates] it".

## Characteristics of Civic Culture

Civic political culture is a mixture of other political cultures namely parochial, subject and participant political cultures.(no content)The term civic culture is used to identify the political culture characteristics that explain the stability of a democratic society's political structure.

Key characteristics include:
- Valuing of active participation in local government activities, parties, and in civic associations
- Strong civic cultures are distinguished by robust support for achieving political homeostasis: the optimal mediated balance between multiple contradictory forces such as in the tension between respect for individual rights and concern for the public good, or that between governmental effectiveness and responsiveness to the interests of citizens.

## Impact on Democratic Societies

The proper combination of the various types of political culture will provide a culture that has a positive implication for the growth of democracy.

Here are the search results for "Disinformation":

## Definition and Characteristics

Disinformation is false or misleading information deliberately spread to deceive people, or to secure economic or political gain and which may cause public harm.(no content)Disinformation is an orchestrated adversarial activity in which actors employ strategic deceptions and media manipulation tactics to advance political, military, or commercial goals.(no content)In contrast, misinformation refers to inaccuracies that stem from inadvertent error.(no content)Scholars collectively agree that disinformation is the strategic dissemination of false information with the intention to cause public harm; misinformation represents the unintentional spread of false information; and malinformation is factual information disseminated with the intention to cause harm.

## Methods and Distribution

Disinformation circulates on social media through deception campaigns implemented in multiple ways including: astroturfing, conspiracy theories, clickbait, culture wars.

## Etymology and History

The English word disinformation comes from the application of the Latin prefix dis- to information making the meaning "reversal or removal of information".(no content)Some consider it a loan translation of the Russian дезинформация, transliterated as dezinformatsiya, apparently derived from the title of a KGB black propaganda department.(no content)Disinformation first made an appearance in dictionaries in 1985, specifically, Webster's New College Dictionary and the American Heritage Dictionary.(no content)By 1990, use of the term disinformation had fully established itself in the English language within the lexicon of politics.

Links: [{"title":"Visual communication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visual_communication"},{"title":"Journal of Visual Communication and Image Representation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Journal_of_Visual_Communication_and_Image_Representation"},{"title":"Visual Communications - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visual_Communications"},{"title":"Visual Communication (journal) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visual_Communication_(journal)"},{"title":"Visual Communication Quarterly - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visual_Communication_Quarterly"},{"title":"Graphic communication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graphic_communication"},{"title":"Communication design - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communication_design"},{"title":"Paul Martin Lester - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Martin_Lester"},{"title":"Visible light communication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visible_light_communication"},{"title":"Graduation Day (upcoming film) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graduation_Day_(upcoming_film)"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of visual communication:

## Definition and Importance

Visual communication relies on a collection of activities, communicating ideas, attitudes, and values via visual resources, i.e. text, graphics, or video.(no content)Visual communication has become one of the most important approaches using which people communicate and share information.

## Components and Elements

Within modern culture, there are several types of characteristics when it comes to visual elements, they consist of objects, models, graphs, diagrams, maps, and photographs. Outside the different types of characteristics and elements, there are seven components of visual communication: color, shape, tones, texture, figure-ground, balance, and hierarchy.

## Visual Communication Tools

Whether it is advertisements, teaching and learning, or speeches and presentations, they all involve visual aids that communicate a message. In reference to the visual aids, the following are the most common: chalkboard or whiteboard, poster board, handouts, video excerpts, projection equipment, and computer-assisted presentations.

## Evaluation and Analysis

The evaluation of a good visual communication design is mainly based on measuring comprehension by the audience, not on personal aesthetic and/or artistic preference as there are no universally agreed-upon principles of aesthetics.(no content)Visual communication holds a specific purpose in aspects such as social media, culture, politics, economics, and science.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Video synthesis"

Links: [{"title":"Video synthesizer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Video_synthesizer"},{"title":"Text-to-video model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Text-to-video_model"},{"title":"Synthesia (company) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synthesia_(company)"},{"title":"Synthetic media - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synthetic_media"},{"title":"Video synopsis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Video_synopsis"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Synthesis on video games - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Synthesis_on_video_games"},{"title":"Software synthesizer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Softsynth"},{"title":"Synthesia - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synthesia"},{"title":"Stratovox - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stratovox"},{"title":"Syntorial - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Syntorial"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of video synthesis:

## Video Synthesizer (Hardware)

A video synthesizer is a device that electronically creates a video signal and is able to generate a variety of visual material without camera input through the use of internal video pattern generators.(no content)It can also accept and "clean up and enhance" or "distort" live television camera imagery.(no content)The history of video synthesis is tied to a "real time performance" ethic, with equipment usually expected to function on input camera signals the machine has never seen before, delivering a processed signal continuously and with a minimum of delay in response to the ever-changing live video inputs.

## AI-Based Video Synthesis

In modern applications, video synthesis refers to AI-generated video content:

A text-to-video model is a form of generative artificial intelligence that uses a natural language description as input to produce a video relevant to the input text.(no content)Advancements during the 2020s in the generation of high-quality, text-conditioned videos have largely been driven by the development of video diffusion models.(no content)In February 2023, Runway released Gen-1 and Gen-2, among the first commercially available text-to-video and video-to-video models accessible to the public through a web interface. Additionally, in June 2024, Luma Labs launched its Dream Machine video tool.

A text-to-video model is a form of generative artificial intelligence that uses a natural language description as input to produce a video relevant to the input text.(no content)Advancements during the 2020s in the generation of high-quality, text-conditioned videos have largely been driven by the development of video diffusion models.(no content)In February 2023, Runway released Gen-1 and Gen-2, among the first commercially available text-to-video and video-to-video models accessible to the public through a web interface. Additionally, in June 2024, Luma Labs launched its Dream Machine video tool.

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about deepfakes:

## Definition

Deepfakes are images, videos, or audio that have been edited or generated using artificial intelligence, AI-based tools or audio-video editing software.(no content)The term "deepfake" was coined in 2017 on a Reddit forum where users shared altered pornographic videos created using machine learning algorithms.(no content)Deepfakes uniquely leverage machine learning and artificial intelligence techniques, including facial recognition algorithms and artificial neural networks such as variational autoencoders (VAEs) and generative adversarial networks (GANs).

## Types and Applications

Deepfakes exist in multiple forms:
- **Video deepfakes**: Face-swapping and video manipulation
- **Audio deepfakes**: Audio deepfake based on imitation is a way of transforming an original speech from one speaker so that it sounds spoken like another speaker.
- **Image deepfakes**: Manipulated or generated images

## Concerns and Misuse

Academics have raised concerns about the potential for deepfakes to promote disinformation and hate speech, as well as interfere with elections.(no content)A 2023 analysis found that 98% of deepfake videos online are pornographic, with 99% of the victims being women.(no content)In 2019, scammers using AI impersonated the voice of the CEO of a German energy company and directed the CEO of its UK subsidiary to transfer €220,000. In early 2020, the same technique impersonated a company director as part of an elaborate scheme that convinced a branch manager to transfer $35 million.

## Legislative Responses

The TAKE IT DOWN Act was introduced by Senator Ted Cruz in June 2024, passed both houses by near unanimous votes by April 2025, and was signed into law by President Donald Trump on May 19, 2025. This law targets non-consensual intimate imagery and deepfakes posted online.

Web search results for query: "Uncertainty"

Links: [{"title":"Uncertainty - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uncertainty"},{"title":"Uncertainty principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uncertainty_principle"},{"title":"Measurement uncertainty - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Measurement_uncertainty"},{"title":"Knightian uncertainty - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knightian_uncertainty"},{"title":"Uncertainty quantification - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uncertainty_quantification"},{"title":"Uncertainty management theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uncertainty_management_theory"},{"title":"Propagation of uncertainty - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Propagation_of_uncertainty"},{"title":"Uncertainty avoidance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uncertainty_avoidance"},{"title":"Fear, uncertainty, and doubt - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fear,_uncertainty,_and_doubt"},{"title":"Uncertainty coefficient - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uncertainty_coefficient"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of uncertainty:

## Definition

Uncertainty is the lack of certainty, a state of limited knowledge where it is impossible to exactly describe one or more of the following: the existing state or goal or set of options, the full set of possible future states or their probabilities or their values or utilities to stakeholders, the full set of stakeholders involved, or any other piece of information that inhibits the calculation of the full set of expected values for the options available.

## Uncertainty vs. Risk

An important distinction is between uncertainty and risk. In economics, in 1921 Frank Knight distinguished uncertainty from risk with uncertainty being lack of knowledge which is immeasurable and impossible to calculate.(no content)To Knight, uncertainty is uninsurable while risk is (hypothetically) insurable.

## Key Types of Uncertainty

The search results reveal several domains where uncertainty is studied:

- **Physics**: The uncertainty principle states that there is a limit to the precision with which certain pairs of physical properties, such as position and momentum, can be simultaneously known. In other words, the more accurately one property is measured, the less accurately the other property can be known.

- **Measurement**: No measurement is exact. When a quantity is measured, the outcome depends on the measuring system, the measurement procedure, the skill of the operator, the environment, and other effects.

- **Psychology/Culture**: Hofstede's uncertainty avoidance scale shows the want to reduce any visible uncertainty that is placed in the life of a person.

Uncertainty is a fundamental aspect of human knowledge and decision-making across multiple disciplines.

Links: [{"title":"Category:Political video games - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Political_video_games"},{"title":"Category:Political satire video games - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Political_satire_video_games"},{"title":"Chad Prather - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chad_Prather"},{"title":"Viral video - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Viral_video"},{"title":"Mashup (video) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mashup_(video)"},{"title":"Vox (website) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vox_(website)"},{"title":"Power Politics (video game) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_Politics_(video_game)"},{"title":"The Political Machine - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Political_Machine"},{"title":"The Agenda Project: America the Beautiful - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Agenda_Project:_America_the_Beautiful"},{"title":"Social impact of YouTube - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_impact_of_YouTube"}]

I've completed a web search for "Political video." Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Viral videos are videos that become popular through a viral process of Internet sharing, primarily through video sharing websites such as YouTube as well as social media and email.

## Political Videos in Campaigns

The 2008 United States presidential election showcased the impact of political viral videos.(no content)For the first time, YouTube hosted the CNN-YouTube presidential debates, calling on YouTube users to pose questions.

Notable examples from that election include a music video featuring a girl claiming to have a crush on presidential candidate Barack Obama that appeared in June 2007.(no content)YouTube became a powerful source of campaigning for the 2008 Presidential Election, with every major party candidate having their own YouTube channel to communicate with voters, with John McCain posting over 300 videos and Barack Obama posting over 1,800 videos.

## Political Mashup Videos

Political video mashups are a primary example of citizen-generated content that allows the creator to form new meanings by juxtaposing two pieces of original source material. A notable example is Hillary 1984, a mashup of Apple's 1984 launch commercial with footage of Hillary Clinton that went viral in March 2007 during the early stages of the race for the 2008 Democratic presidential nomination.

## YouTube's Role in Politics

YouTube has affected conventional politics, becoming even more important than direct mail in political campaigning, with politicians and governments using the website to directly engage citizens and promote policies.

I've completed a web search for "Political video." Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Viral videos are videos that become popular through a viral process of Internet sharing, primarily through video sharing websites such as YouTube as well as social media and email.

## Political Videos in Campaigns

The 2008 United States presidential election showcased the impact of political viral videos.(no content)For the first time, YouTube hosted the CNN-YouTube presidential debates, calling on YouTube users to pose questions.

Notable examples from that election include a music video featuring a girl claiming to have a crush on presidential candidate Barack Obama that appeared in June 2007.(no content)YouTube became a powerful source of campaigning for the 2008 Presidential Election, with every major party candidate having their own YouTube channel to communicate with voters, with John McCain posting over 300 videos and Barack Obama posting over 1,800 videos.

## Political Mashup Videos

Political video mashups are a primary example of citizen-generated content that allows the creator to form new meanings by juxtaposing two pieces of original source material. A notable example is Hillary 1984, a mashup of Apple's 1984 launch commercial with footage of Hillary Clinton that went viral in March 2007 during the early stages of the race for the 2008 Democratic presidential nomination.

## YouTube's Role in Politics

YouTube has affected conventional politics, becoming even more important than direct mail in political campaigning, with politicians and governments using the website to directly engage citizens and promote policies.

Here are the search results for "Social media":

## Overview

Social media platforms allow individuals, communities, businesses, and organizations to share, co-create, discuss, participate in, and modify user-generated or self-curated content.(no content)According to Merriam-Webster's 2019 definition, social media refers to "forms of electronic communication (such as websites for social networking and microblogging) through which users create online communities to share information, ideas, personal messages, and other content (such as videos)."

## Uses

Social media is used to share memories, form friendships, build communities and learn. They may be used to promote people, companies, products, and ideas. Social media can be used to consume, publish, or share news.

## Popular Platforms

Popular social media platforms with over 100 million registered users include Twitter, Facebook, WeChat, ShareChat, Instagram, Pinterest, QZone, Weibo, VK, Tumblr, Baidu Tieba, Threads and LinkedIn.(no content)Other popular platforms that are sometimes referred to as social media services include YouTube, Letterboxd, QQ, Quora, Telegram, WhatsApp, Signal, LINE, Snapchat, Viber, Reddit, Discord, and TikTok.

## Growth and Adoption

As of 2023, as many as 4.76 billion people used social media some 59% of the global population.

## Differences from Traditional Media

Social media outlets operate in a dialogic transmission system (many sources to many receivers) while traditional media operate under a monologic transmission model (one source to many receivers).

## Criticisms

Social media has been criticized for a range of negative impacts on children and teenagers, including exposure to inappropriate content, exploitation by adults, sleep problems, attention problems, feelings of exclusion, and various mental health maladies.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title, relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results, relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Perfect! I have successfully completed the analysis of the paper on deepfakes and disinformation. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Summary

**Paper Classification:** Contribution

**Triples Extracted (8 total):**

1. **Deepfake** (artifact) - proposes
   - Paper examines the societal and political impact of deepfake synthetic videos on public trust and discourse

2. **Disinformation** (concept) - uses
   - Paper integrates existing theories about how disinformation undermines trust in news and media

3. **Artificial intelligence** (concept) - uses
   - AI is the enabling technology that creates deepfakes and synthetic videos analyzed in the paper

4. **Synthetic media** (artifact) - proposes
   - Paper studies effects of synthetic media technology on viewer perception and trust in political context

5. **Visual communication** (concept) - uses
   - Paper integrates theories about the persuasive power of visual communication in understanding deepfake impact

6. **Uncertainty** (concept) - uses
   - Paper builds on uncertainty theory to explain how deepfakes increase doubt and reduce trust in media

7. **Social media** (tool) - uses
   - Social media is the distribution platform where deepfakes spread and where trust in news is measured

8. **Civic political culture** (concept) - uses
   - Paper examines how deepfakes threaten democratic civic culture and public discourse institutions

**Validation Result:** ✅ All validation checks passed successfully

The analysis correctly identifies this as a contribution paper (proposing new empirical findings about deepfakes) that builds upon existing concepts including disinformation, uncertainty theory, and visual communication. The paper proposes examining deepfakes and synthetic media in the context of their impact on democratic societies.

Sources:
- [Deepfake](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deepfake)
- [Disinformation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disinformation)
- [Artificial intelligence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence)
- [Synthetic media](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synthetic_media)
- [Visual communication](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visual_communication)
- [Uncertainty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uncertainty)
- [Social media](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_media)
- [Civic political culture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civic_political_culture)

## Analysis Summary

**Paper Classification:** Contribution

**Triples Extracted (8 total):**

1. **Deepfake** (artifact) - proposes

2. **Disinformation** (concept) - uses

4. **Synthetic media** (artifact) - proposes
   - Paper studies effects of synthetic media technology on viewer perception and trust in political context

5. **Visual communication** (concept) - uses

   - Paper builds on uncertainty theory to explain how deepfakes increase doubt and reduce trust in media

7. **Social media** (tool) - uses
   - Social media is the distribution platform where deepfakes spread and where trust in news is measured

8. **Civic political culture** (concept) - uses
   - Paper examines how deepfakes threaten democratic civic culture and public discourse institutions
